coredata.dc:title: Molecular structure adjustment enhanced anti-oxidation ability of polymer electrolyte for solid-state lithium metal battery

coredata.dc:description: Poly(vinyl ethylene carbonate) (PVEC) electrolyte is one of the preferable choices for solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs). However, the poor anti-oxidation ability still hinders its practical application for high-energy SSLMBs with high-voltage cathodes. Herein, the strategy of molecular structure adjustment is proposed for improving the properties of PVEC, which exhibits the widened electrochemical stability window (4.8 V vs. Li+/Li) and high ionic conductivity (1.1 × 10−3 S cm1 at 25 °C). The compatibilities of cathode/electrolyte and anode/electrolyte interfaces are also enhanced respectively by eliminating the weak bonding of polymer molecular structure and forming Li x Sn alloy during the ring-opening polymerization. The solid-state batteries with LiCoO2 cathode exhibit the high capacity when charged to 4.5 V at 25 °C. Therefore, this work not only demonstrates the effective method to enhance the interfacial compatibility between electrolyte and electrode, but also affords an emerging design strategy for polymer electrolyte by breaking the unstable weak bonding for the application requirements of SSLMBs.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: a, The schematic diagram of molecular structure adjustment for C-PVEC and R-PVEC by different catalyst/initiator. b. The electron localization function of VEC monomer (number is the bond order of C-O and CO bond for -OCOO- bond in ring structure). c, The crosslink network structure of C-PVEC form VEC through Sn(Oct)2 catalyzation. The comparisons of d, 1H NMR spectra and e, FT-IR spectra of VEC+Li salt precursor, R-PVEC, and C-PVEC.

a, HOMO and LUMO energy levels of R-PVEC and C-PVEC. b, The electrochemical stability window of R-PVEC and C-PVEC. c, The C 1s XPS spectra of R-PVEC and C-PVEC after different constant current-current voltage charging tests. d, The temperature dependency of ionic conductivity of C-PVEC and R-PVEC. e, Chronoamperometry profile of the Li/C-PVEC/Li symmetric battery under a polarization potential of 10 mV, and the EIS before and after the polarization (insert).

a, The electrostatic potentials of R-PVEC and C-PVEC. b, 6,7Li NMR spectra and the simulations of C-PVEC after different cycle times in Li/C-PVEC/Li symmetric battery. The relative occupancies are marked with each spectrum. c, Schematic diagram of ions migration pathways in C-PVEC.

a, The potential profiles of repeated Li plating/striping in Li/R-PVEC/Li and Li/C-PVEC/Li symmetric batteries with current density of 0.5 mA cm−2. The XPS spectra of b, Li 1s and c, Sn 3d for Li metal after Li plating/stripping test. The SEM images of Li anode surface after test of battery with (d) R-PVEC and (e) C-PVEC. f, The EDS mapping of Li anode surface after test of battery with C-PVEC. The simulated Li dendrite growth with different nucleation sites for battery with (g) R-PVEC and (h) C-PVEC.

a, The comparisons of leakage current plots for LCO/R-PVEC/Li and LCO/C-PVEC/Li batteries at constant voltage of 4.5 V. b, The 1H NMR spectra of R-PVEC and C-PVEC after test. c, Rate performances of LCO/C-PVEC/Li and LCO/C-PVEC/Li batteries under cut-off voltage of 4.5 V. d, Comparisons of charge-discharge curves of the LCO/R-PVEC/Li and LCO/C-PVEC/Li batteries at current density of 0.5 C. e, The cycling stabilities of LCO/R-PVEC/Li and LCO/C-PVEC/Li batteries under cut-off voltages of 4.4 and 4.5 V, respectively.

head.ce:title: Molecular structure adjustment enhanced anti-oxidation ability of polymer electrolyte for solid-state lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Poly(vinyl ethylene carbonate) (PVEC) electrolyte is one of the preferable choices for solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs). However, the poor anti-oxidation ability still hinders its practical application for high-energy SSLMBs with high-voltage cathodes. Herein, the strategy of molecular structure adjustment is proposed for improving the properties of PVEC, which exhibits the widened electrochemical stability window (4.8 V vs. Li+/Li) and high ionic conductivity (1.1 × 10−3 S cm1 at 25 °C). The compatibilities of cathode/electrolyte and anode/electrolyte interfaces are also enhanced respectively by eliminating the weak bonding of polymer molecular structure and forming Li x Sn alloy during the ring-opening polymerization. The solid-state batteries with LiCoO2 cathode exhibit the high capacity when charged to 4.5 V at 25 °C. Therefore, this work not only demonstrates the effective method to enhance the interfacial compatibility between electrolyte and electrode, but also affords an emerging design strategy for polymer electrolyte by breaking the unstable weak bonding for the application requirements of SSLMBs.

The wide electrochemical stability window (4.8 V vs. Li+/Li) and high ionic conductivity (1.1 × 10−3 S/cm at 25 °C) are offered by Poly(vinyl ethylene carbonate) (PVEC) electrolyte with molecular structure adjustment. The compatibilities of cathode/electrolyte and anode/electrolyte interfaces are enhanced by eliminating the weak bonding of polymer molecular structure and forming alloy on anode surface during the ring-opening polymerization. This study not only demonstrates the effective method to enhance the interface compatibility between electrolyte and electrode, but also offers a design strategy for polymer electrolyte by breaking the unstable weak bonding for the application requirements of solid-state lithium metal batter.
ga1

ce:section.ce:para: With the increasing demand of high energy devices for practical applications in electric vehicles and electronic devices, the lithium metal batteries (LMBs) have been strongly considered in recent years [1,2]. However, the liquid organic electrolyte based LMBs suffer from security problems that caused by the uncontrollable growth of lithium dendrites, which eventually penetrate through the separator and result in the short-circuit [3–5]. Different from the methods for protecting Li metal in LMBs with liquid electrolyte, the applications of solid electrolytes are considered as the fundamental and effective strategy to improve the safety [6–8]. The polymer electrolytes (PEs) have been widely investigated in the past decades due to their good flexibility for interface contact and processing, and the convenience of tunable components and electrochemical properties [9–11]. However, the PEs have some challenges, especially the ionic conductivities are not comparable to those of liquid electrolytes (10−3–10−2 S cm−1 at 25 °C), narrow electrochemical stability window and poor interface compatibility with high-voltage cathode, which cannot satisfy the requirement of solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs) [12–15]. Therefore, various PEs have been proposed to offer the relatively high ionic conductivities at 25 °C, including the poly-1,3-dioxolane [16], poly(vinyl ethylene carbonate) [17], poly(vinylene carbonate acrylonitrile) based gel polymer electrolytes [18] and poly(vinylidenefluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene)/Li6.05Ga0.25La3Zr2O11.8F0.2 composite electrolyte [19]. Besides, the poly(fluoroethylene carbonate) [20], PEO/Li6.75La3Zr1.75Ta0.25O12 [21] and Ca-CeO2/PEO composite electrolyte [22] have been reported to extend the electrochemical stability windows.

In general, the stability of polymer chain is highly related to the interior molecular structure, which is determined by the strength of intrinsic bonding energy [23,24]. The PEs are fabricated by dissolving the lithium salts in the polymer matrix, in which the electrochemical stability window is decided by the stabilities of these components. With the strong resistance of Li salt decomposition, the strength of molecular structure of polymer matrix is crucial for the strong anti-oxidation ability of PEs, which can be enhanced by eliminating the weak bonding with low energy [20,25]. For instance, the strategy of functional units adjustment is proposed to improve the comprehensive properties of PEs [26,27]. Furthermore, Sun [28] and co-authors revealed that the reactive terminal -OH group is the limiting factor towards applicability for high-voltage cathode, which can be replaced by the more stable -OCH3 group. The electrochemical stability window can be extended from 4.05 to 4.3 V (vs. Li+/Li). However, the ionic conductivity is still low and not satisfactory for the high-performance SSLMBs.

In this work, based on the poly(vinyl ethylene carbonate) (PVEC) electrolyte that we reported earlier, the strategy of molecular structure adjustment is proposed by breaking the weak bonding in advance and followed by the polymerizing, which can extend the electrochemical stability window and afford high ionic conductivity. The ring-opening polymerization is revealed by theoretical calculations and experimental results, and the interface compatibilities between electrolyte and cathode/anode can be enhanced by eliminating the weak bonding of molecular structure and forming alloy on Li metal surface. The electrochemical performances of SSLMBs with LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode are significantly improved when charged to 4.5 V. Consequently, this study affords an effective method to enhance the anti-oxidation ability of PEs for the practical applications of high-energy SSLMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Fabrication of solid polymer electrolyte and solid polymer battery
ce:section.ce:para: The PVEC was fabricated by in-situ synthesis method can complete the fabrication of PVEC and the formation of SSLMBs in one step. Firstly, liquid VEC monomer (10 g) and bistrifluoromethanesulfonimide lithium salt (LiTFSI, 3 g) were added into the glass bottle under stirring to form a homogeneous solution. Then, the tin(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (Sn(Oct)2) as the catalyst, was added into the solution and stirred for 3 h to form a homogeneous solution in glove box, without any other solvent. Subsequently, the solution with 20 μL was injected into Whatman® filter (100% borosilicate glass fiber) in coin-type battery (CR2032), which was adopted as separator between cathode and anode to prevent the internal short circuit of the battery before the polymerization of polymer electrolyte. After that, the battery was assembled and transferred to a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 24 h to make the complete polymerization of PVEC polymer electrolyte (C-PVEC). Adopting the same preparation method, 2,2′-Azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN, 1 wt%) replace Sn(Oct)2 as an initiator, to render the complete polymerization of PVEC polymer electrolyte (R-PVEC).

The Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FT-IR) was carried out using a Nexus 870 FTIR spectrometer with the ATR instrument to distinguish the structures of liquid VEC monomer, R-PVEC and C-PVEC. The morphology of the C-PVEC and Li metal was characterized by a field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800). The high-resolution solid-state Magic Angle Spinning Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (MAS NMR) spectra were carried out on a Bruker 400 MHz spectrometer equipped with a Bruker 4.0 mm double resonance MAS probe at the 1H, 13C, 6Li, and 7Li Larmor frequencies of 400.17 and 100.62 MHz, respectively. All samples were packed into 4.0 mm zirconia rotors with Kel-F drive caps in an Argon-filled glovebox, and were then spun at 6.0 kHz ± 3 Hz using a Bruker pneumatic MAS unit. The 90° pulse for 1H excitation was determined as 2.9 µs and total 4 scans were accumulated for one spectrum. High power decoupling was applied on 1H during 13C acquisition. For signal-averaging, total 512 transitions were accumulated for all samples. The 1H and 13C chemical shifts were referenced to the proton and the secondary carbon atom in adamantane at 1.8 ppm and 38 ppm, respectively. Spectra were recorded after single-pulse excitation with repetition times of 5, 1 and 1 s for studying 6Li and 7Li nuclei, respectively. GPC measurements was performed by dissolving the synthesized C-PVEC in Trichloromethane and eluting the solutions in a Waters ambient temperature GPC equipped with triple detection capability for absolute polymer molecular weight determination. The crystal structure of the C-PVEC was characterized via X-rays diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance) with range of 10°–80°. For the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), the binding energies were calibrated according to the peak of 284.8 eV in the C1s spectrum.

The ionic conductivity of C-PVEC was calculated by bulk resistance (Rb) from electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) at varied temperatures ranging from −15 °C to 55 °C. The Rb of C-PVEC was determined from the impedance spectrum that sandwiched between two stainless-steel (SS) plate electrodes and the spectra were recorded in the frequency range of 0.1–105 Hz with an AC amplitude of 10 mV. The ionic conductivity was calculated from equation: σ =

, where R b is the bulk resistance, L and S are the thickness and area of the C-PVEC-SPE, respectively. The electrochemical stability window was investigated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) performed on a working electrode of SS, Li metal as the counter and reference electrode of R-PVEC/C-PVEC at a scan rate of 1.0 mV s−1 between 2.5 and 5.5 V. The Li ions transference number (tLi +) was calculated by the chronoamperometry test on the Li/C-PVEC/Li symmetry battery with an applied voltage of 0.01 V and was determined by following equation:

The tests were completed by EIS measurements taken before and after the polarization scans over a frequency range of 0.1–105 Hz with a 10 mV amplitude at 25 °C. The test sample of polymer electrolyte was removing from after in-situ complete polymerization.

The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and molecular electrostatic potential of polymers were performed by Gaussian 16 package. Geometric configurations were optimized at the B3LYP-D3 level with a 6–311 + G (d, p) basis set. The 6–311 +G(d, p) basis set is a split-valence triple-zeta basis with diffuse s and p functions for nonhydrogen atoms. Such basis set has good accuracy, and widely used in previous works. The vibrational frequency calculations were performed at the same computational level to confirm that the configurations were energetic minima. The bond order was calculated by Multifwn [29].

The Li dendrite growth morphology in Li metal anodes with or without metal/alloy is simulated by the phase field model, involving Butler-Volmer kinetics. A phase field order parameter ξ was introduced to describe Li deposition: ξ = 1 denotes the Li metal phase and ξ = 0 denotes the electrolyte phase.

This lithium plating phase field model was simulated on COMSOL Multiphysics 5.5 platform. A two-dimensional domain with a size of 60 µm × 30 µm with multiple nucleation sites on the bottom boundary is introduced. Li nucleation spacing is set as 20 µm for the R-PVEC based Li metal anode, and 4 µm for the C-PVEC based Li metal anode, respectively. The constant Li plating current density is 10.0 mA cm−2, and the total plating areal capacity is 1.0 mAh cm−2. Related theory, model details, and parameter values can be found in references [30–32].

The LCO was composed of 80 wt% LCO, 10 wt% carbon black, 10 wt% binder (PVDF: VEC-LiTFSI-AIBN/Sn(Oct)2 = 7:3). The mass loading of cathode material with areal density was 2 mg cm−2. The C rates in all the electrochemical measurements are defined based on 1 C= 160 mAh g−1 for LCO. The battery was assembled in an argon-filled glove box, with oxygen content less than 1 ppm and H2O content less than 1 ppm. The galvanostatic charge/discharge tests of CR2032 were conducted on LAND testing system (Wuhan LAND electronics Co., Ltd.) at 25 °C.

The PVEC electrolyte with five-membered ring (R-PVEC) can be obtained by the polymerization of unsaturated functional groups (CC bonds) in VEC monomer with AIBN as the initiator (right part of Fig. 1a) [17]. However, the electrochemical stability window of R-PVEC is still narrow, which is induced by the weak bonding energy of ring structure (to be decomposed at high charge voltage). The polycarbonate electrolyte with chain structure owns the enhanced anti-oxidation ability [33–35]. In order to expand the electrochemical stability window, the molecular structure of PVEC electrolyte has been adjusted by breaking the ring structure and forming rigid crosslink network in advance, from which the weak bonding can be eliminated. The schematic diagram shows that the polycarbonate electrolyte with chain structure (C-PVEC) can be fabricated through the simultaneous ring-opening and addition polymerizations from VEC monomer by using Sn(Oct)2 catalyst (left part of Fig. 1a). The possible polymerization process has been clarified by theoretical simulation and experimental analysis. Firstly, the location for the ring-opening of VEC monomer is theoretically explored by electron localization function (ELF) of VEC monomer and bond order of C-O and CO bonds for -OCOO- in ring structure. As shown in Fig. 1b, the O2 atom on CO group has a stronger polarity, and is easy to be intramolecularly attacked by the Sn+ in Sn(Oct)2, leading to the rearrangement of -OCOO- bond in ring structure [36,37]. Besides, the C-O1 bond exhibits a lower bond order and ELF than that of C-O2 and C-O3 bonds, which indicate the weak bonding of C-O1 bond and much easier to be broken. The detailed process for the ring-opening polymerization of C-PVEC is shown in Fig. S1, which involves a coordinative insertion of VEC monomer into “Sn-O” bond of catalyst [38,39]. Furthermore, the crosslink network structure of C-PVEC is formed due to the simultaneous addition and ring-opening polymerization of VEC monomer, and then the structure stability can be further increased (Fig. 1c).

The polymerization of PVEC with adjustable molecular structures by different catalysts/initiator is further probed by the solid state 1H Magic Angle Spinning Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (MAS NMR) spectroscopy. The signals in the range of 5.2∼6.0 ppm (H atoms at a, b and c position on CH2 =CH- bond in Fig. 1a) in VEC monomer almost disappear after polymerization reaction in both R-PVEC and C-PVEC (Fig. 1d). Meanwhile, two new peaks at 1.91 and 2.28 ppm are observed, which are for the terminal H atoms on C-C bonds in R-PVEC and C-PVEC. The different peaks at 2.78 ppm (c′) and 2.72 ppm (c′′) are found for R-PVEC and C-PVEC, respectively. The spectral changes between the VEC monomer and polymers have confirmed the successful polymerization by different catalyst/initiator [40]. For the 1H spectrum of VEC monomer, the peaks at 4.69 and 4.23 ppm are assigned to the protons at d and e/f positions in five-membered ring. The intensity of proton at e/f is not twice of the one at d position, which is possibly due to the faster relaxation caused by the neighboring oxygen atom. After polymerization, these signals move to 4.19 and 3.40 ppm (d′ and e′/f′) for the 1H NMR spectra of VEC and R-PVEC, respectively [40]. These shifts are caused by the change of electron configuration from the CC to C-C bond. However, for the C-PVEC that polymerized by Sn(Oct)2 catalyst, the signals of the two protons at e′′ and f′′ positions are different from that at 3.35 and 3.54 ppm, which are due to the different environments caused by the opening of five-membered ring, and are similar to the other polycarbonates [36,38]. The ring-opening polymerization of C-PVEC can be achieved by Sn(Oct)2 catalyst. Furthermore, all signals in C-PVEC show broadened linewidth due to more rigid crosslink network by breaking five-membered ring, when compared to that of R-PVEC from the addition polymerization. Moreover, from the 13C NMR spectra in Fig. S2, there is no obvious signal for CC bond (located at 133 and 121 ppm) in C-PVEC, indicating the sufficient addition polymerization from VEC monomer. More importantly, the ring-opening polymerization has been further confirmed by the blue shifts for the signal of carbons at c, d, and e positions, corresponding to the shifts of resonances from 78, 69, and 156 ppm to 120, 122 and 178 ppm, respectively. Thus, the polymerization is successfully tracked by solid-state NMR spectra and can be easily manipulated by applying proper catalyst for desired molecular structure.

The molecular structure adjustment between R-PVEC and C-PVEC have also been detected by FT-IR. The peak at ∼1640 cm−1 for CC bond in VEC monomer disappears after polymerization, and the new peaks at ∼720 cm−1 for C-C bonds can be found in both R-PVEC and C-PVEC (Fig. 1e). The peak at ∼1790 cm−1 represents the CO bond in the five-membered ring of carbonate ester, while the peak at ∼1768 cm−1 can be assigned to CO bond in the chain structure. [41] There is no obvious change of CO bond at 1790 cm−1 for VEC and R-PVEC, indicating the five-membered ring can be maintained after polymerization by AIBN initiator (Fig. 1a). Differently, there is a strong peak at ∼1768 cm−1 for CO bond in C-PVEC, demonstrating the polycarbonate with chain structure can be obtained after polymerization by Sn(Oct)2 catalyst. Furthermore, the new peaks at ∼1435 and ∼1289 cm−1 in C-PVEC are attributed to -COOH groups on the terminals of polycarbonates, consisting with the polymerization process. Therefore, the NMR and FT-IR spectra have confirmed the adjustable molecular structure of PVEC electrolyte, which has been achieved successfully by the addition or ring-opening polymerization from same VEC precursor with different catalyst/initiator.

By the adjustment of molecular structure, it is estimated that the anti-oxidation ability of C-PVEC electrolyte can be enhanced and the electrochemical stability window can be expanded. The anti-oxidation and anti-reduction abilities of PEs are closely related to the Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels, respectively [20,42]. Consequently, the LUMO and HOMO energy levels of R-PVEC and C-PVEC are firstly analyzed by DFT calculations. As shown in Fig. 2a, the C-PVEC exhibits a lower HOMO energy level than that of R-PVEC, indicating the enhanced anti-oxidation ability of polycarbonate with chain structure. In addition, the C-PVEC exhibits the lower LUMO energy level, in which the reduction reaction occurs more easily at the interface with Li metal. Then the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer can form and prevent the further decomposition of electrolyte. The theoretical calculations have demonstrated the enhanced anti-oxidation ability of PVEC electrolyte by eliminating the weak bonding of five-membered ring.

Furthermore, the electrochemical stability window of PVEC with different molecular structure has been explored by LSV test of the Li/PVEC/SS battery. Fig. S3 shows the effect of mass fraction of catalyst on the electrochemical stability window of C-PVEC, demonstrating the sufficient ring-opening polymerization can be achieved by optimizing the content of catalyst. With the mass fraction of catalyst of 2 wt%, the electrochemical stability window of C-PVEC can be up to 4.8 V (vs. Li+/Li), which is higher than 4.5 V of R-PVEC (Fig. 2b). In addition, the XPS is employed to detect the chemical components of PE membranes before and after constant current-constant voltage charging at 4.3 V and 4.7 V for 50 h (Fig. 2c). For the C1s spectra of R-PVEC, the typical peaks for C-C bond (∼284.8 eV), C-O bond (∼286.7 eV), -CO3 bond (∼290.6 eV), -CF3 bond (∼292.5 eV), and -OCOO- bond in ring structure (∼288.3 eV) of five-membered ring can be found in the pristine state [43]. However, the area ratio for each peak has varied when the battery was charged to 4.3 V. The reduction of area ratio for the -OCOO- bond indicates the instability of five-member ring, which starts to decompose at this charge voltage. Even worse, when the battery was charged to 4.7 V, the peak for -OCOO- bond in five-membered ring has fully disappeared, and a new peak at ∼288.9 eV for -OCOO- bond in chain structure can be observed, which are attributed to the full decomposition of five-member ring in R-PVEC [44,45]. On the contrast, for the C-PVEC that formed by ring-opening polymerization, there is no obvious change of the peak at ∼288.9 eV for -OCOO- bond in chain structure, even the battery was charged to 4.7 V. More importantly, there is no other peak that newly formed during the charge process, indicating the stability of molecular structure in C-PVEC. Therefore, the LSV test and XPS spectra have further confirmed the enhanced anti-oxidation ability of C-PVEC with chain structure, in which the electrochemical stability window reaches to 4.8 V.

The ionic conductivity (σ) of PE is critical for SSLMBs. Fig. 2d shows the σ of R-PVEC and C-PVEC at various temperature, which is obtained by using the R b from the EIS of SS/R-PVEC/SS and SS/C-PVEC/SS symmetrical batteries (Fig. S4). The σ increases with the rise of temperature, and can be up to 1.1 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C. The tendency of σ in C-PVEC is much similar to that of R-PVEC (2.08 ×10−3 S cm−1, 25 °C), while the electrochemical stability window has been expanded obviously. The high ionic conductivities for both C-PVEC and R-PVEC should be primarily attributed to the local interactions between Li ions and functional groups of CO/C-O-C bonds in the polycarbonate electrolyte [17]. From the temperature-dependent behavior of σ, the activation energy (Ea) of C-PVEC is ~ 0.06 eV, indicating a low energy barrier for Li ions migration at various temperature, and be beneficial for keeping the high ionic conductivity. Besides, the electronic conductivity of C-PVEC is ∼2.52 × 10−10 S cm−1, and inhibits the growth of Li dendrite effectively (Fig. S5) [46].

The tLi + is also critical for the practical application of PE for SSLMBs. From the direct current polarization and EIS tests in Fig. 2e, the tLi + of C-PVEC is ∼0.58 at 25 °C, which is higher than 0.40 of R-PVEC [17]. The high tLi + of C-PVEC is caused by the strong electron withdrawing capability of CO and C-O-C groups in chains. The ion pairing of TFSI- anions for PVEC with different structures has been compared in Fig. S6. When compared to 60% for R-PVEC, the area ratio of free ions decreases to 44% for C-PVEC, indicating the limited movement of salt anoins (TFSI-) by the crosslinked skeleton in C-PVEC [47]. Therefore, the high tLi + in C-PVEC reduces the side reaction on the surface of electrodes and the concentration polarization of anions, and then improves the rate performance of batteries [48]. Besides, the interface contact between C-PVEC and Li metal anode is also analyzed by the polarization test (inset in Fig. 2e). There is no obvious change of EIS for the symmetrical battery before and after polarization, indicating the stable interface contact between C-PVEC and Li metal. Moreover, the surface of C-PVEC membrane is homogenous with dense structure (Fig. S7), which can effectively form the intimate contact with electrodes, and provide enough ions migrations. From the XRD pattern of electrolyte membrane, the C-PVEC has a low crystallinity structure, which is similar with that of R-PVEC, and is beneficial for fast Li ions migration (Fig. S8).

In order to reveal the origin for the high ionic conductivity, the pathways for ions migration in C-PVEC has been systematically investigated. Firstly, the electrostatic potential (ESP) has been theoretically simulated, in which the electric density maps of C-PVEC and R-PVEC can be obtained ( Fig. 3a). The region around O atoms on CO groups in R-PVEC has higher electron density with negative charge (the red area), indicating the strong interactions between CO groups and Li ions. In contrast, the electron density of region around O atoms on CO groups in C-PVEC decreases significantly, and demonstrates the weak interactions with Li ions. In addition, the Li ions distributions in C-PVEC are probed by solid-state 6,7Li NMR, and the spectra are shown in Fig. 3b. The electrolyte membrane is obtained by disassembling the Li/C-PVEC/Li symmetric battery after different cycles. There is one 7Li NMR resonance centered at 0.48 ppm that can be observed for the pristine C-PVEC, and the signal shifts to low field after cycling for 30 and 60 min. The polarized signal can be simulated as two peaks at 0.51 and 0.54 ppm for the location of Li ions at C-O and CO groups respectively. Furthermore, the peak width increases slightly upon longer cycling time, which might be caused by a soften process via the transport of Li ions along CO and C-O groups in C-PVEC. Especially, the area ratios for the two signals at 0.51 and 0.54 ppm do not show obvious change for different cycling time, indicating good electrochemical stability due to the rigid crosslink structure. Thus, the stable interactions between ions and CO/C-O groups can be maintained after different cycle time in C-PVEC, which are different from that of R-PVEC. Moreover, with the better resolution, the 6Li NMR spectra of above C-PVEC sample are also performed and similar results are obtained (the right of Fig. 3b). It has confirmed the interactions between ions and C-O groups (the intensity ratio is near 50%) are also important for the fast ion migration.

Combing the theoretical simulations and experimental results, the interior ions migration mechanism in C-PVEC can be proposed as follows (Fig. 3c). The fast ions migration can be mainly achieved by the local interactions (the coupling and decoupling) between Li ions and O atoms of CO/C-O groups, which afford the high ionic conductivity of C-PVEC at 25 °C. Furthermore, there are moving/exchange of Li ions between CO and C-O groups during the segmental motion of polymers. The ions migration mechanism in C-PVEC is much different from that of R-PVEC, which should be originated from the adjustment of molecular structure. Obviously, the intensity ratio for the local interaction between Li ions and O atoms of C-O groups is much close to that of CO groups in C-PVEC with chain structure, and is higher than that in R-PVEC with five-membered ring. Furthermore, the low crystallinity and reduced activation energy of C-PVEC are also favorable for fast ion migrations [17].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Protective effect on Li metal anodes
ce:section.ce:para: Besides the ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability window, the interface compatibility between C-PVEC and electrode is another critical factor for the high-performance SSLMBs. The in-situ polymerization is beneficial for enhancing interface contact and reducing interface resistance [17], and has been applied for assembling the SSLMBs based on C-PVEC. Firstly, the interface contact and interface resistance (R i) between C-PVEC and Li metal anode has been explored by the SEM and EIS of Li/C-PVEC/Li symmetrical battery, which was fabricated via in-situ process from the ring-opening polymerization. For comparison, the Li/R-PVEC/Li battery is also assembled by the same process with different initiator. From the cross-sectional SEM image of Li/C-PVEC interface, the intimate contact without crack can be achieved after the in-situ polymerization (Fig. S9). Furthermore, the interface stability between C-PVEC and Li metal anode is investigated by polarization test of Li/C-PVEC/Li battery with the constant current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 at 25 ℃ ( Fig. 4a). Obviously, the Li/R-PVEC/Li battery exhibits the high voltage polarization with overpotential of ∼1.86 V and cannot work after 50 h. However, the Li/C-PVEC/Li battery can work steady for 800 h without short circuiting under the same test condition. Moreover, the voltage polarization is pretty low and the overpotential is ∼0.04 V, which is much lower than that Li/R-PVEC/Li battery. These results indicate the good reversibility and cycling stability of lithium plating/stripping in C-PVEC based SSLMBs.

The possible reason for the long cycling stability with low voltage polarization of Li/C-PVEC/Li battery is explored by XPS and SEM. The solid-state batteries based on C-PVEC is disassembled after 400 cycles, and the chemical components of Li and Sn elements on the surface of Li metal anode are firstly detected by XPS. According to the Li 1s spectra in Fig. 4b, there are two peaks at 55.4 and 56.3 eV that can be attributed to the Li salt and Li x Sn alloy, respectively. The Li x Sn alloy that formed on the surface of Li metal anode can regulate the dispersion of current, mitigate the Li ions concentration gradients, inhibit the dendrite formation and promote the ion diffusion [39,49,50]. From the Sn 3d spectra, the peaks at 484.9 and 493.3 eV are relating to metallic Sn (Fig. 4c). In addition, the peaks located at 487.1 and 495.4 eV are corresponding to the formation of SnO2. As shown in Fig. 4d, a large number of disordered dendrites form on the surface of Li anode for R-PVEC based battery (after cycling for 50 h), which cause the short cycling stability and high voltage polarization. On the contrast, the uniform dendrite on the surface of Li anode can be obtained from the C-PVEC based battery after 800 h (Fig. 4e), which is favorable for the cycling stability and low voltage polarization. Besides, the Sn element is probed on the surface of Li metal from the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping (Fig. 4f).

Furthermore, the lithium dendrite growth on the surface of Li anode with or without metal/alloy is numerically modeled by the phase field method [30,51]. For the two-dimension model consisting of random electronic and ionic conductive channels in R-PVEC based SSLMBs, there are only few Li nucleation sites on the surface of metal anode at the initial electroplating process (Fig. 4g). The Li dendrites not only vertically grow toward the R-PVEC from the surface of Li anode with the single nucleation site, but also grow in the lateral direction without controllable size. Therefore, the growth of Li dendrites with radial pattern are obtained at the high current density, in which the electrodeposited Li grows from single nucleation site to large tree-like dendrites at hemispherical directions on anode surface. These results are consisting with the SEM image of Li dendrites for R-PVEC in Fig. 4d. On the contrast, with the wide dispersions of metallic Sn and Li x Sn alloy on the surface of Li anode, there are many Li nucleation sites (high density of nucleation number) at the initial electroplating process in the two-dimension model with same size (Fig. 4h). Meanwhile, the channels and dispersions of electrons and ions conduction can be regulated by Sn and Li x Sn alloy. The growth of electrodeposited Li can be regulated, in which the large tree-like dendrite can be inhibited, and the size can be reduced simultaneously. The uniform and smooth dendrite on the surface of Li anode can be obtained, which has also been revealed in Fig. 4e for C-PVEC. Therefore, with the formation of metallic particles and alloys on the surface of Li anode via the ring-opening polymerization of C-PVEC by Sn(Oct)2) catalyst, the dendrite growth can be effectively regulated during the lithium plating/stripping, which are beneficial for the long cycling stability with low voltage polarization of C-PVEC based SSLMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Universality of PVEC in Li-LiCoO2 batteries
ce:section.ce:para: With the enhanced anti-oxidation ability of C-PVEC, the interface compatibility with high-voltage LCO cathode has been explored by charging/discharging and leakage current test of SSLMBs. The in-situ polymerization method is applied to assemble the solid-state battery. Fig. S10 exhibits the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery under a current density of 0.1 C (1 C=160 mAh g−1) in the voltage range of 3.0–4.6 V at 25 °C. The battery can be charged to 4.6 V with the steady curve, and displays the initial discharge capacity of ∼200 mAh g−1. However, the charge voltage of LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery cannot reach to 4.6 V at the same test condition, and the overcharge occurs at the charge voltage of ∼4.5 V. The failure of LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery should be caused by the instability and decomposition of five-member ring at this charge voltage, which has been clarified in Fig. 2c. Therefore, the stability of interface contact with high-voltage LCO cathode can be improved by the molecular structure adjustment of C-PVEC, which is favorable for constructing the high energy SSLMBs. However, the oxidative decomposition of PE was further catalyzed by transition metal ions in LCO cathode at high charge voltage [52,53]. Thus, the cycling stability of LCO/C-PVEC/Li is poor with the charge voltage of 4.6 V, and the discharge capacity decays dramatically within 10 cycles.

In order to improve the cycling stability of SSLMBs, the interface compatibility between C-PVEC and LCO cathode is evaluated in the voltage range of 3.0–4.5 V. Firstly, the leakage current has been collected for the battery with the constant voltage charging at 4.5 V ( Fig. 5a). The leakage current of LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery exhibits the rapid and steady descent without significant fluctuation, demonstrating the C-PVEC has structural stability and good interface compatibility with LCO cathode. Nevertheless, there is a significant fluctuation with current spike before equilibrium in the leakage current of LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery. It indicates a large polarization during the constant voltage charging at 4.5 V, which should be caused by the breaking of weak bonding in five-membered ring of R-PVEC.

Furthermore, the interfacial resistances of LCO/PVEC/Li battery before and after constant voltage charging (4.5 V for 50 h) have been explored by EIS (Fig. S11). There is no obvious change for the interfacial resistance of LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery, indicating the favorable interface contact that derived from the structural stability of electrolyte. In contrast, the interface resistance decreases significantly in the LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery, which is caused by the severe oxidation decomposition of R-PVEC, and could result in a rapid capacity decay. Moreover, the chemical structure of PVEC after constant voltage charging is analyzed by solid state 1H NMR (Fig. 5b). Obviously, the signals for protons of -O-CH2-O- group in C-PVEC keep stable for different time, while the significant increases of relative intensities for the corresponding signals can be observed for R-PVEC. These results demonstrate the structure stability of C-PVEC with chain structure, and the severe decomposition of R-PVEC with five-membered ring during the charging process up to 4.5 V [54]. Therefore, the favorable interface compatibility between C-PVEC and LCO cathode at charge voltage of 4.5 V is beneficial for enhancing the electrochemical performances of SSLMBs.

The electrochemical performances of LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery in the voltage range of 3.0–4.5 V have been explored at 25 °C. Fig. 5c shows the rate performances of both LCO/C-PVEC/Li and LCO/R-PVEC/Li batteries with the current densities increases from 0.1 to 1 C. The LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery exhibits the specific capacity of ∼116 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, and ∼106 mAh g−1 at 1 C, which are much larger than that of LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery. The charge/discharge curves of two batteries at different current densities are shown in Fig. S12, in which the overpotentials increase with the rise of current densities. The polarization of LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery is much smaller than that of LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery. As shown in Fig. 5d, the LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery exhibits the initial discharge capacity of ~149 mAh g−1 with Coulombic efficiency of ~93%, which are much better than that of LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery. The large capacity and low polarization of LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery are related to the enhanced interface compatibility and improved tLi +, in which the side reaction between electrolyte and cathode is reduced, and the distribution of ions concentration is uniformed. Fig. 5e compares the cycling stabilities of different solid-state batteries. The LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery owns the high capacity over 100 cycles at 0.5 C. However, the capacity of LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery decays fast for 30 cycles. Furthermore, the high capacity retention of ∼89% over 100 cycles can be obtained for LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery at 1 C with the charge potential of 4.4 V, which is also much better than that of LCO/R-PVEC/Li battery (Fig. 5e and S13). The good cycling stability and rate performances of LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery are generated from the enhanced anti-oxidation ability of C-PVEC with chain structure, and the favorable interface compatibility with high-voltage LCO cathode.

Furthermore, with the relatively high ionic conductivity for C-PVEC at 5 °C, the LCO/C-PVEC/Li battery was tested at this temperature (Fig. S14). The battery delivers the high discharge capacity of ∼145 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and good cycle performance at 0.2 C under cut-off voltage of 4.5 V, indicating the possible application of C-PVEC based SSLMBs at relatively low temperature. Moreover, the LCO/C-PVEC/Li pouch cell is fabricated to evaluate the practical application in electrochemical energy storage (Fig. S15). The cell lights up the logo with 70 light-emitting diode (LED) lamps without short-circuit after cutting-off. Therefore, as the enhanced interface compatibility with high-voltage LCO cathode, the C-PVEC is a promising candidate for the practical application in high-energy SSLMBs with favorable electrochemical performances.

The C-PVEC polymer electrolyte with wide electrochemical stability window of 4.8 V and high ionic conductivity of 1.1 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C is fabricated by adjusting the molecular structure. The anti-oxidation ability of electrolyte and interface compatibility with high-voltage cathode are significantly enhanced by breaking the weak bonding of five-membered ring during the polymerization process, which are confirmed by theoretical simulations and experimental characterizations. The interfacial compatibility with Li anode is also enhanced by Li x Sn alloy that formed on the surface of metal anode after the polymerization by Sn(Oct)2 catalyst. The C-PVEC based SSLMBs with LiCoO2 cathode exhibit a high capacity over 100 cycles when charged to 4.5 V at 25 °C. Therefore, this work not only demonstrates an effective method to enhance the interfacial compatibility between polymer electrolyte and electrodes by molecular structure adjustment, but also offers a design strategy for developing polymer electrolyte by breaking the unstable weak bonding for application requirements of SSLMBs.

H.Y. conceived and designed this work. Z.L. carried out the experiments and wrote the manuscript. Z.L., X,G., P.D., L.W. and Y.W. designed the figures. M.T. helped with the NMR measurements. Z.Z. and S.Z. helped with the Density functional theory. R.Z. helped Phase field theory simulations. Q.Z. contributions to the scientific discussion. All authors participated in analyzing the experimental results and preparing the manuscript.
